Award.AwardTitle: Promoting Foundational Scientific Literacy Skills in Introductory Psychology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A rising tide of calls for improved science education underscores the importance and significance of incorporating stronger training of scientific thinking skills into first-year college science courses. This project addresses that need by developing, evaluating, and disseminating a set of scientific thinking teaching materials with proven efficacy in a variety of college settings. The materials will use core topics in Introductory Psychology in combination with real world issues and controversies to train students' scientific thinking skills. The project builds on cognitive psychology research on human learning and established best-practices for science education.

The overarching goals of the project are to develop, evaluate, and disseminate a set of flexible, research-based teaching modules to improve the training of scientific literacy and quantitative reasoning skills in Introductory Psychology. The project will develop a set of scientific thinking instructional modules, keyed to the major topics covered in Introductory Psychology. A unique element of the project is its intentionally collaborative framework, which involves a network of faculty from four academic sites in Oregon including two community colleges (CCs), a large four-year Research 1 institution (R1), and a selective, liberal arts undergraduate college (SLAC). This inter-institutional network will collaborate on the development and formative assessment of all resources, including identifying adaptations of modules for different course formats and student needs. A comprehensive assessment plan will provide a summative assessment of the effectiveness of the teaching modules at all three institution types (CC/R1/SLAC) prior to broader dissemination to the psychology teaching community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF project applied the science of teaching and learning to the development and evaluation of materials to train scientific reasoning in college students. Materials were developed for use in Introductory Psychology, which is a heavily subscribed first-year science course. The materials were designed to meet the need for teaching resources that (a) are based on existing cognitive science research on learning, (b) follow best-practices for STEM education, (c) can be easily adapted by instructors teaching in different settings, and (d) are demonstrably effective in diverse classroom contexts.

 

The final curriculum included eight modular activities to train scientific reasoning skills. Each modular activity was keyed to a major unit in Introductory Psychology (e.g., Developmental Psychology; Social Psychology; Personality Psychology) and required 30-45 minutes of class time. All modules involved the analysis of data from a published study related to a real-world issue (e.g., treatments for depression, teen drivers). Activities were designed to engage students in different aspects of scientific reasoning skills (e.g., interpreting data in tables and graphs, reasoning about research design and appropriate conclusions). Separate versions of the modules were developed for use with (1) small classes of <50 students and (2) larger lecture-style classes with 100+ students.

 

Modules were evaluated in three different educational settings: a community college, a small liberal arts college, and a large state school. Using a pre-/post- assessment, gains in a set of scientific reasoning outcomes were compared among students in classes where the modules were used relative to students in classes taught as usual. In all three instructional settings, students in classes using the modules showed larger gains in scientific reasoning.

 

These findings suggest that flexible, research-based materials to train scientific reasoning can be successfully implemented in a range of Introductory Psychology courses, resulting in large gains in student learning. Both the small-class and large-class versions of the scientific literacy curriculum are now posted for free access by any instructor, including an accessible version of the large class modules for use with students who have visual impairments. A version that can be used for fully online teaching is also available as an LMS export from the authors. As well, the materials have been published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at several conferences, reaching both research- and teaching-focused faculty from diverse institutions and settings.
